an10.12:4.1: “Mendicants, in this teaching and training a mendicant who has given up five factors and possesses five factors is called consummate, experienced, a supreme person.
an10.12:4.2: And how has a mendicant given up five qualities?
an10.12:4.3: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
an10.12:4.4: That’s how a mendicant has given up five qualities.
an10.12:5.1: And how does a mendicant have five factors?
an10.12:5.2: It’s when a mendicant has the entire spectrum of a master’s ethics, samādhi, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.
an10.12:5.3: That’s how a mendicant has five factors.
an10.12:6.1: In this teaching and training a mendicant who has given up five factors and possesses five factors is called consummate, experienced, a supreme person.”
an10.12:7.4: are not found in a mendicant at all.
